greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct primes which occur as substrings of the digits of n.
comment: a(A062115(n))=0; a(A093301(n))=n and a(m)<>n for m < A093301(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 16 2007
link: R. Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(22)=1 because 22 has two substrings which are prime but they are identical. a(103)=2, since the primes 3 and 103 occur as substrings.
mathematica: a[n_] := Block[{s = IntegerDigits[n], c = 0, d = {}}, l = Length[s]; t = Flatten[ Table[ Take[s, {i, j}], {i, 1, l}, {j, i, l}], 1]; k = l(l + 1)/2; While[k > 0, If[ t[[k]][[1]] != 0, d = Append[d, FromDigits[ t[[k]] ]]]; k-- ]; Count[ PrimeQ[ Union[d]], True]]; Table[ a[n], {n, 1, 105}]
program: a039997 n = length [p | p <- takeWhile (<= n) a000040_list,
xref: Different from A039995 after the 100th term. Cf. A035232.
results.author: _David W. Wilson_
ext: Edited by _Robert G. Wilson v_, Feb 24 2003
